title: The business logic of sustainability - Ray Anderson

options.label: C
options.text: Consumerism and waste

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: The Interface plan is to become a sustainable company by 2020 and to reach the top of the "Mountain of Sustainability".

multiple-choice.question: What is the revised environmental impact equation proposed by Ray Anderson, and what does it suggest?

options.label: A
options.text: I = P * A * T (Impact = Population * Affluence * Technology)

options.label: B
options.text: I = P * A / T (Impact = Population * Affluence / Technology)

options.label: C
options.text: I = P / A * T (Impact = Population / Affluence * Technology)

options.label: D
options.text: I = P * T / A (Impact = Population * Technology / Affluence)

options.label: C
options.text: Attraction of top talent and goodwill in the marketplace

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The next generation

options.label: D

title: Mysteries of vernacular: Robot - Jessica Oreck and Rachael Teel

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the word "robot"?

options.label: A
options.text: It comes from the Latin word for "machine".

options.label: B
options.text: It comes from the Old Church Slavonic word "rabota", describing forced labor of the people.

options.label: C
options.text: It comes from the Czech word "robota", describing hard work or drudgery.

options.label: D
options.text: It comes from the English word "laborer".

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Modern robots have not risen up against humans.

options.label: D
options.text: Modern robots are less popular.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of forced labor.

options.label: C
options.text: A form of hard work or drudgery.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of automation.

multiple-choice.question: What is one common characteristic that defines a vampire?

options.label: A
options.text: They are all undead.

options.label: B
options.text: They all have superhuman strength.

options.label: C
options.text: They sustain themselves by consuming the life force of a living creature.

options.label: D
options.text: They all have fangs.

options.label: C

title: The strengths and weaknesses of acids and bases - George Zaidan and Charles Morton

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of strong acids?

options.label: A
options.text: They donate just a few protons to water.

options.label: B
options.text: They accept just a few protons from water.

options.label: C
options.text: They donate many protons to water.

options.label: D
options.text: They accept many protons from water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for when a proton-deposit customer (acid) and a proton-withdrawal customer (base) interact, resulting in a neutral effect on water's account?

options.label: A
options.text: Neutralization

options.label: B
options.text: Acid-base reaction

options.label: C
options.text: Chemical equilibrium

options.label: D
options.text: Molecular exchange

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of weak acids and bases?

options.label: A
options.text: They donate or accept many protons to or from water.

options.label: B
options.text: They donate or accept just a few protons to or from water.

options.label: C
options.text: They are always neutral in water.

options.label: D
options.text: They never interact with water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process by which acids and bases exchange protons and electrons with their surroundings?

options.label: A
options.text: Acid-base reaction

options.label: B
options.text: Chemical equilibrium

options.label: C
options.text: Molecular exchange

options.label: D
options.text: Chemical interaction

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of water in acid-base chemistry?

options.label: A
options.text: It can only act as an acid.

options.label: B
options.text: It can only act as a base.

options.label: C
options.text: It can act as either an acid or a base.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no role in acid-base chemistry.

title: Toy tiles that talk to each other - David Merrill

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the development of SIF tables?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a new type of computer mouse

options.label: B
options.text: To build a system that can sense and respond to physical motion

options.label: C
options.text: To design a new type of keyboard

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a new programming language

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the unique features of SIF tables?

options.label: A
options.text: They can only be moved by a computer mouse

options.label: B
options.text: They can sense each other and their motion

options.label: C
options.text: They can only display text

options.label: D
options.text: They are only available for desktop computersAnswer: B: They can sense each other and their motion

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a new interaction style that can be explored with SIF tables?

options.label: A
options.text: Using a keyboard to type out a message

options.label: B
options.text: Pouring a color from one SIF table to another

options.label: C
options.text: Using a mouse to click on a button

options.label: D
options.text: Using a touchscreen to swipe through a menuAnswer: B: Pouring a color from one SIF table to another

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential applications of SIF tables in education?

options.label: A
options.text: To teach programming languages

options.label: B
options.text: To help students learn math and logic concepts

options.label: C
options.text: To teach a new language

options.label: D
options.text: To help students learn how to use a computer mouseAnswer: B: To help students learn math and logic concepts

title: What is the shape of a molecule? - George Zaidan and Charles Morton

multiple-choice.question: What is the shape of a molecule, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A statue-like shape with distinct boundaries

options.label: B
options.text: A shape that is mostly empty space, with atoms and electrons arranged to maximize attraction and minimize repulsion

options.label: C
options.text: A shape that is determined by the number of atoms in the molecule

options.label: D
options.text: A shape that is constant and unchanging

multiple-choice.question: What is the chemical formula of methane, and what does it tell us about the molecule?

options.label: A
options.text: CH4 tells us that every molecule of methane is made up of one carbon and four hydrogen atoms, and that they are all bonded to each other

options.label: B
options.text: CH4 tells us that every molecule of methane is made up of one carbon and four hydrogen atoms, but it doesn't tell us what's bonded to what or how they are arranged in 3D space

options.label: C
options.text: CH4 tells us that every molecule of methane is made up of one carbon and four oxygen atoms

options.label: D
options.text: CH4 tells us that every molecule of methane is made up of two carbon and two hydrogen atoms

multiple-choice.question: What is the shape of the methane molecule, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A pyramid

options.label: B
options.text: A straight line

options.label: C
options.text: A tetrahedron

options.label: D
options.text: A bent shape like an elbow

multiple-choice.question: What determines the shape of a molecule, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of atoms in the molecule

options.label: B
options.text: The type of atoms involved

options.label: C
options.text: The arrangement of bonded atoms to maximize attraction and minimize repulsion

options.label: D
options.text: The number of electrons in the molecule

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the shape of a molecule as you increase the number of atoms, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The shape becomes simpler and more predictable

options.label: B
options.text: The shape becomes more complicated and harder to predict

options.label: C
options.text: The shape remains the same, regardless of the number of atoms

options.label: D
options.text: The shape becomes random and unpredictable

title: The uncertain location of electrons - George Zaidan and Charles Morton

multiple-choice.question: What determines the identity of an atom?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of neutrons in its nucleus

options.label: B
options.text: The number of protons in its nucleus

options.label: C
options.text: The number of electrons in its nucleus

options.label: D
options.text: The number of atoms in a molecule

multiple-choice.question: Why can't we exactly say where electrons are in an atom?

options.label: A
options.text: Because we don't have the equipment to measure them

options.label: B
options.text: Because electrons are too small to see

options.label: C
options.text: Because the uncertainty is part of our model of the electron

options.label: D
options.text: Because electrons are too fast to track

multiple-choice.question: What are the shapes that chemists call "orbitals"?

options.label: A
options.text: The shapes that atoms take in a crystal lattice

options.label: B
options.text: The shapes that molecules take in a solution

options.label: C
options.text: The shapes that describe the probability of finding an electron in a given space around the nucleus

options.label: D
options.text: The shapes that describe the motion of atoms in a gas

multiple-choice.question: Why did the chemist pick 95% as the probability of finding an electron within a given shape?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's a magic number that has no scientific basis

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's the probability of finding an electron at the nucleus

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's the probability of finding an electron at a distance from the nucleus where the probability starts to decrease exponentially

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's the probability of finding an electron in a given shape that is not dependent on energy

multiple-choice.question: What determines almost everything about the nature of the world around us?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of atoms in a molecule

options.label: B
options.text: The number of electrons in an atom

options.label: C
options.text: The dynamics of the social network of atoms, including how they give up or share electrons

options.label: D
options.text: The number of protons in an atom

title: Why I'm a weekday vegetarian - Graham Hill

multiple-choice.question: Why was the speaker initially hesitant to adopt a vegetarian diet?

options.label: A
options.text: He was concerned about the taste of plant-based food.

options.label: B
options.text: He was pitched a binary solution that didn't align with his lifestyle.

options.label: C
options.text: He was worried about the cost of plant-based food.

options.label: D
options.text: He was unsure about the nutritional value of plant-based food.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's "Weekday Veg" program?

options.label: A
options.text: A program to reduce meat intake to only one day a week.

options.label: B
options.text: A program to eat only plant-based food on weekdays and meat on weekends.

options.label: C
options.text: A program to reduce meat intake to five days a week, with the option to break the rule on weekends.

options.label: D
options.text: A program to eliminate all animal products from one's diet.

multiple-choice.question: What are the major culprits in terms of environmental damage and health?

options.label: A
options.text: Red and processed meats, as well as sugary drinks.

options.label: B
options.text: Red and processed meats, as well as dairy products.

options.label: C
options.text: Red and processed meats, as well as sustainably harvested fish.

options.label: D
options.text: Red and processed meats, as well as organic produce.

multiple-choice.question: What are the benefits of adopting the "Weekday Veg" program?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced pollution, improved health, and financial savings.

options.label: B
options.text: Improved health, increased energy, and a smaller carbon footprint.

options.label: C
options.text: Reduced waste, increased productivity, and a more balanced diet.

options.label: D
options.text: Improved relationships, increased happiness, and a more fulfilling life.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if everyone ate half as much meat as they do now?

options.label: A
options.text: It would have a minimal impact on the environment and animal welfare.

options.label: B
options.text: It would be like half of the population adopting a vegetarian diet.

options.label: C
options.text: It would lead to an increase in meat production and consumption.

options.label: D
options.text: It would have no impact on the environment and animal welfare.

title: Why don’t oil and water mix? - John Pollard

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why oil does not dissolve in water?

options.label: A
options.text: The attractive forces between oil and water molecules are too weak.

options.label: B
options.text: The size of oil molecules is too big for the water molecules to accommodate.

options.label: C
options.text: The oil molecules are not great dancers and disrupt the dance of water molecules.

options.label: D
options.text: The entropy of oil molecules is too high.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the attractive forces between molecules?

options.label: A
options.text: Energetics

options.label: B
options.text: Entropy

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen bonding

options.label: D
options.text: Molecular interactions

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the molecular structure of water and oil?

options.label: A
options.text: Water molecules are bigger than oil molecules.

options.label: B
options.text: Oil molecules are arranged in a brick wall formation, while water molecules are in a square dance.

options.label: C
options.text: Water molecules have a higher entropy than oil molecules.

options.label: D
options.text: Oil molecules are more attracted to each other than water molecules are.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of entropy in the dissolution of substances in water?

options.label: A
options.text: Entropy favors the separation of substances in water.

options.label: B
options.text: Entropy favors the mixing of substances in water.

options.label: C
options.text: Entropy has no effect on the dissolution of substances in water.

options.label: D
options.text: Entropy is the primary reason why salt dissolves in water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the addition of salt ions to water?

options.label: A
options.text: The salt ions disrupt the hydrogen bonding network of water molecules.

options.label: B
options.text: The salt ions are repelled by the water molecules and do not join the dance.

options.label: C
options.text: The salt ions add more possible dance positions in the square dance, favoring them to stay dancing with water.

options.label: D
options.text: The salt ions have no effect on the dance of water molecules.

title: The science of stage fright (and how to overcome it) - Mikael Cho

multiple-choice.question: What is stage fright, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A fear of being seen as an awful idiot

options.label: B
options.text: A natural, hormonal, full-body reaction by an autonomic nervous system

options.label: C
options.text: A feeling of excitement before speaking in public

options.label: D
options.text: A lack of preparation before a speech

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why humans experience stage fright?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are afraid of failure

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are wired to worry about reputation

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not well-prepared

options.label: B
options.text: The neck and back relax, and the legs and hands become calm

options.label: C
options.text: The neck and back tense up, and the legs and hands shake

options.label: D
options.text: The blood pressure drops, and the pupils constrict

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to adapt to stage fright?

options.text: To practice a lot and start rehearsing weeks in advance

options.label: B
options.text: To stretch your arms up and breathe deeply before speaking

options.label: C
options.text: To try to overcome the fear of being seen as an awful idiot

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on what you can control and practice in a similar environment

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome when you approach the microphone with a clear voice and a relaxed body?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: You adapt to stage fright and convince the crowd that you're a charismatic genius

options.label: C
options.text: You experience a panic attack and faint

options.label: D
options.text: You become nervous and stutter
